Welcome to the dev community! Both Paul and Alonâ€™s explanations are spot on, Iâ€™ll just add a bit more detail in case it helps.

When people say Kaia is EVM-compatible, it means that Kaia supports the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM), the â€œengineâ€ that runs smart contracts on Ethereum. Thanks to this, developers can use familiar tools, and even deploy existing Ethereum apps on Kaia with little to no changes.

So if youâ€™re new to blockchain, EVM compatibility basically means you donâ€™t have to learn a whole new system, a lot of what works on Ethereum will also work on Kaia.

For more details, you can check this out: https://www.coingecko.com/learn/ethereum-virtual-machine-evm

latest_posts.name: Lewis @Kaia
latest_posts.cooked:
Hi, thanks for your interest.

As you already know, Kaia has also been working to adopt the Pectra HF, and weâ€™ll definitely bring the major EIPs in Pectra on Kaia!

Since there are design differences between Kaia vs Ethereum, there are also EIPs that we donâ€™t need to bring; for example, blob-related things and EIP-7251. We donâ€™t have the concept of MAX_EFFECTIVE_BALANCE for stakers, so thereâ€™ll be no EIP-7251 on Kaia. And also, EOF was originally expected to be included in Pectra but was delayed to Fusaka, and finally decided to be removed from Fusaka after discussion recently. So we also wonâ€™t bring EOF.

But EIP-7702, which is the key concept to explore the UX, will also be activated on Kaia after Kaiaâ€™s Prague HF.

If you have more questions, please let us know! Thanks for your support again.
latest_posts.topic_title: Pectra Improvements aligns with Kaia goal of scalability and UX. Will Kaia bridge Ethereum pectra upgrade?
latest_posts.topic_html_title: Pectra Improvements aligns with Kaia goal of scalability and UX. Will Kaia bridge Ethereum pectra upgrade?
latest_posts.raw:
Hi, thanks for your interest.

As you already know, Kaia has also been working to adopt the Pectra HF, and we'll definitely bring the major EIPs in Pectra on Kaia!

Since there are design differences between Kaia vs Ethereum, there are also EIPs that we don't need to bring; for example, blob-related things and EIP-7251. We don't have the concept of `MAX_EFFECTIVE_BALANCE` for stakers, so there'll be no EIP-7251 on Kaia. And also, EOF was originally expected to be included in Pectra but was delayed to Fusaka, and finally decided to be removed from Fusaka after discussion recently. So we also won't bring EOF.

But EIP-7702, which is the key concept to explore the UX, will also be activated on Kaia after Kaia's Prague HF.

If you have more questions, please let us know! Thanks for your support again.

Bridging Ethereumâ€™s Pectra Upgrade to Kaia: A Path Forward.

Introduction: Why Pectra Matters for Kaia.

The blockchain ecosystem is in a constant state of evolution, with Ethereum leading many of the most impactful upgrades. The upcoming Pectra upgrade, combining the Prague and Electra hard forks, introduces key improvements that could significantly benefit Kaia, an EVM-compatible blockchain focused on scalability and user experience.

As Ethereum rolls out account abstraction (EIP-7702), staking optimizations (EIP-7251), and EVM bytecode enhancements (EOF), Kaia has a unique opportunity to integrate these innovationsâ€”strengthening its infrastructure, attracting developers, and improving its consensus model. But how feasible is this integration? What challenges might arise? And what strategic steps should Kaia take to adopt these upgrades effectively?

This article explores the connections, risks, and strategies for bringing Ethereumâ€™s Pectra advancements to Kaia.

Understanding Ethereumâ€™s Pectra Upgrade

Key Features of Pectra

Pectra is one of Ethereumâ€™s most anticipated upgrades, introducing several major improvements:

  1. EIP-7702 (Account Abstraction)
  • Allows externally owned accounts (EOAs) to delegate transactions to smart contracts.
  • Enables gasless transactions, batch operations, and sponsored transactions, improving UX for wallets and dApps.
  1. EIP-7251 (Increased Staking Limits)
  • Raises the maximum effective validator balance from 32 ETH to 2,048 ETH.
  • Reduces operational overhead for large stakers, improving capital efficiency.
  1. EVM Object Format (EOF)
  • Restructures EVM bytecode for better security, upgradability, and gas efficiency.
  • Reduces risks like reentrancy attacks while optimizing smart contract execution.

How Pectra Enhances Ethereum

  • Scalability: EOF and EIP-7702 help reduce on-chain congestion.
  • Security: More robust smart contract execution and validator management.
  • User Experience: Smoonder DeFi, gaming, and wallet interactions.

Kaiaâ€™s Current Ecosystem: Strengths and Alignment with Ethereum

Kaiaâ€™s Technical Foundation

  • EVM Compatibility: Full support for Ethereum tools (MetaMask, Hardhat, Foundry).
  • Consensus Mechanism: Hybrid PoS with high throughput (~4,000 TPS).
  • Use Cases: Strong adoption in DeFi, gaming, and enterprise blockchain solutions.

Why Pectraâ€™s Upgrades Are Relevant for Kaia

Since Kaia is EVM-compatible, Ethereumâ€™s upgrades naturally influence its roadmap. Key areas of alignment include:

  • Interoperability: Adopting similar EIPs ensures seamless dApp migration.
  • Staking Efficiency: EIP-7251 could optimize Kaiaâ€™s PoS model.
  • Developer Appeal: Features like account abstraction attract Ethereum developers.

Opportunities for Kaia: How Pectra Can Enhance the Ecosystem

  1. Better EVM Compatibility with EOF
  • Improves smart contract security and efficiency.
  • Ensures Kaia remains competitive with Ethereumâ€™s latest optimizations.
  1. Account Abstraction (EIP-7702) for Superior UX
  • Gasless transactions (sponsored by dApps or wallets).
  • Batch transactions (e.g., approving and swapping tokens in one click).
  • Enhanced wallet security (social recovery, multi-signature schemes).
  1. Staking Improvements via EIP-7251
  • Allows validators to consolidate stakes, reducing node management complexity.
  • Could attract institutional stakers to Kaiaâ€™s network.

Challenges and Risks in Integration

  1. Technical Hurdles
  • EOF Adoption: Requires deep bytecode-level changes in Kaiaâ€™s EVM.
  • Consensus Adjustments: EIP-7251 may need modifications for Kaiaâ€™s PoS model.
  1. Security Considerations
  • EIP-7702 Risks: Malicious invokers could exploit transaction delegation.
  • Governance Complexity: Deciding which EIPs to prioritize without disrupting stability.
  1. Developer and Community Buy-In
  • Requires education, tooling updates, and governance proposals (KIPs).
  • Potential resistance from validators if staking changes affect rewards.

Strategic Recommendations for Kaia

  1. Phased Rollout of Pectra EIPs.
  • Short-Term: Implement EIP-7702 for immediate UX benefits.
  • Medium-Term: Adopt EOF for smarter contract execution.
  • Long-Term: Evaluate EIP-7251 for staking optimizations.
  1. Strengthening Cross-Chain Bridges
  • Improve Klaytn â†” Ethereum bridges (e.g., Orbit, Axelar) for smoother asset and data flow.
  1. Developer Incentives and Governance
  • Host workshops on Pectra EIPs for Kaia developers.
  • Propose KIPs (Kaia Improvement Proposals) to formalize upgrade paths.

Conclusion: Positioning Kaia for the Future

Ethereumâ€™s Pectra upgrade presents a golden opportunity for Kaia to enhance its scalability, security, and user experience while maintaining strong EVM compatibility. By selectively adopting EIP-7702, EOF, and EIP-7251, Kaia can attract more developers, improve validator efficiency, and offer a superior blockchain experience.

However, careful governance, risk assessment, and community engagement will be crucial for a smooth transition. If executed well, Kaia could emerge as a leading high-performance EVM chainâ€”bridging the best of Ethereumâ€™s innovations with its own unique strengths.

latest_posts.name: ian song
latest_posts.cooked:
what happens if like a transaction fails? How will wallets add this feature?

Great question. The receipts of reverting gasless transactions will not be found after some time (10~30s). The wallet will wait for receipts and know the transaction failed if they are not found. It is different from when a normal transaction reverts in that the receipt of the reverted transaction can be found.

latest_posts.name: ian song
latest_posts.cooked:
Good question. If any of the gasless transactions (approve or swap) reverts, then none of the transactions will be included in the block, so itâ€™ll be like the transactions were never sent.
For example, given txs = [ A1 S1 A2 S2 A3 S3 ] (Approve and Swap txs for user 1-3), If S2 reverts, then block will include only [ A1 S1 A3 S3 ].
This is enforced by KIP-245; reverting txs in bundle will be excluded from block.
Note that KIP-245 does not â€œsimulateâ€ the transaction execution; it is difficult to predict if a tx will revert. Instead, transactions in a bundle are actually executed, and rolled-back to pre-execution upon revert.
latest_posts.topic_title: Discussion on KIP-247
latest_posts.raw:
Good question. If any of the gasless transactions (approve or swap) reverts, then none of the transactions will be included in the block, so it'll be like the transactions were never sent.
For example, given `txs = [ A1 S1 A2 S2 A3 S3 ]` (Approve and Swap txs for user 1-3), If S2 reverts, then block will include only [ A1 S1 A3 S3 ].
This is enforced by KIP-245; reverting txs in bundle will be excluded from block.
Note that KIP-245 does not "simulate" the transaction execution; it is difficult to predict if a tx will revert. Instead, transactions in a bundle are actually executed, and rolled-back to pre-execution upon revert.
